entry.et: Middle English swalowe, from Old English swealwe; akin to Old High German swalawa swallow

def.dt: :any of numerous small widely distributed oscine birds (family Hirundinidae, the swallow family) that have a short bill, long pointed wings, and often a deeply forked tail and that feed on insects caught on the wing
:any of several birds that superficially resemble swallows

entry.et: Middle English swalowen, from Old English swelgan; akin to Old High German swelgan to swallow

def.dt: :to take through the mouth and esophagus into the stomach
:to envelop or take in as if by swallowing :absorb swallow the financial loss watch night swallow the valley
:to accept without question, protest, or resentment swallow an insult a hard story to swallow
:take back retract had to swallow my words
:to keep from expressing or showing :repress swallowed my anger
:to utter (as words) indistinctly
:to receive something into the body through the mouth and esophagus
:to perform the action characteristic of swallowing something especially under emotional stress
:the passage connecting the mouth to the stomach
:a capacity for swallowing
:an act of swallowing
:an amount that can be swallowed at one time
:a swallow (Hirundo rustica of the family Hirundinidae) that is widespread in the northern hemisphere, has a deeply forked tail, and often nests in or near buildings
:a colonial swallow (Petrochelidon pyrrhonota) of the New World with a pale buff rump and dark throat patch that builds mud nests resembling jugs especially under eaves and on cliffs
:an American swallow (Tachycineta bicolor syn. Iridoprocne bicolor) with iridescent greenish-blue upperparts and white underparts
:a deeply forked and tapering tail (as of a swallow)
:tailcoat
:any of various usually large brightly marked butterflies (family Papilionidae, especially genus Papilio) with each hind wing typically having an elongated process
